apple: occasional small spots or blemishes on the skin
aquarium_fish: often seen inside an aquarium tank
beaver: presence of a dam or lodge (in natural settings)
bed: situated close to the floor or on legs, commonly found in a bedroom
sometimes accompanied by nightstands or bedside tables
bicycle: possible additional features like fenders, a bell, or a basket
bottle: Possible label or branding on the body
Screw cap, cork, or other type of closure at the top
bowl: smooth surface, possibly decorated or plain
boy: generally shorter stature compared to adults
bridge: Architectural details varying by type (e.g., suspension, arch, beam)
Visible supports, like pillars or piers
bus: a prominent door, usually at the front or middle
multiple pairs of wheels, usually larger than car wheels
a front windshield, often broad and wide
camel: often seen in desert or arid surroundings
a small head with large eyes and long eyelashes
distinctive humps on its back (one or two, depending on the species)
caterpillar: numerous legs, usually with a pair per segment
sometimes small, horn-like projections or spines
cattle: Long tail with a tuft of hair at the end
chair: presence of a frame or structure providing stability
four legs (usually, but can vary with design)
varying styles, such as dining chairs, office chairs, armchairs, etc.
a seat which may be padded or unpadded
chimpanzee: bare face with expressive eyes, often resembling a human's
clock: numbers or hour markers arranged in a circle or on a face
commonly found on walls, desks, or as part of electronic devices
a frame or casing around the face
a visible or hidden mechanism for the hands (analog) or an LCD/LED display (digital)
cloud: often irregular shapes but may appear to form identifiable patterns
white, grey, or variably colored atmospheric mass
can have varying degrees of translucence or opacity
can be observed in different weather conditions (clear, rainy, stormy)
couch: commonly found in living rooms or seating areas
crab: usually a rounded or slightly oval shape
crocodile: usually greenish-brown or grey in color
elongated snout with sharp, visible teeth
eyes and nostrils positioned on top of the head
cup: may have visible contents such as coffee, tea, or another beverage
may have a saucer underneath it (sometimes)
a handle on one side (often, but not always)
a small, cylindrical or conical container
typically made of ceramic, glass, plastic, metal, or paper
dinosaur: possible presence of horns, frills, or crests
often depicted with a more upright or horizontal posture
dolphin: a distinctive, curved mouth that often appears to be smiling
elephant: short tail with a tuft of hair at the end
flatfish: a mouth that may appear skewed to one side
eyes located on the same side of the head
forest: possibly wildlife like birds, insects, or small mammals
fox: Dark markings on the legs and behind the ears
Bushy tail, often with a white tip
girl: Facial features such as a smaller nose, rounder face, and larger eyes
Engaging in activities typically associated with children, such as playing with toys, attending school, or participating in sports or hobbies.
kangaroo: large snout with a distinctive muzzle
keyboard: branding or logo, often seen above or below the keys
a space bar, usually the longest key located at the bottom row
lamp: typically slender and vertical, though there are various styles (e.g., table lamps, floor lamps, desk lamps)
a base or stand to support it
lawn_mower: a motor or engine, either gasoline-powered or electric
a handle or steering wheel for pushing or guiding
often a pull cord or battery compartment for starting
a collection bag or chute for grass clippings
leopard: black rosette-shaped spots with a central spot (rosettes)
piercing eyes, usually green or gold
relatively short legs compared to body size
lion: distinctive facial features, including a broad nose and strong jaw
a long tail with a tuft of fur at the end
often seen in open grasslands or savannas
lobster: two large claws (one crusher claw and one pincher claw)
man: Shorter hair (note: not exclusive to men)
motorcycle: Footrests for the rider and possibly a passenger
Exhaust pipe(s) extending from the engine
Seat (often elongated for rider and sometimes a passenger)
Engine typically located below the seat
mountain: Often part of a mountain range or series of connected peaks
May cast shadows depending on the light source
oak_tree: branches that spread outward, often forming a wide crown
orange: often seen with leaves attached (in some photos)
otter: typically seen near water sources such as rivers, lakes, or the ocean
playful behavior often depicted (e.g., floating or playing with objects)
palm_tree: Crown of large, fan-shaped or feather-like leaves (fronds) at the top
Often found in tropical or subtropical environments
pear: a rounded bottom that tapers towards the top
pickup_truck: a vehicle with an open cargo area or bed
usually a larger and taller body compared to standard cars
often equipped with a towing hitch
plain: horizon line that is often quite straight and visible
occasional presence of bodies of water like rivers or lakes
plate: usually has a slight rim or lip around the edge
often found in a kitchen or dining setting
may contain food or be part of a place setting
made of materials like ceramic, plastic, glass, or metal
raccoon: small, rounded ears with white edges
alternating dark and light rings on the tail
ray: eyes and spiracles (small openings for breathing) located on top of the body
gill slits located on the underside
rocket: pointed nose cone at the top
often white, with metallic or black sections and sometimes national or organizational insignia
sometimes emitting smoke or flame if in launch phase
large fins or stabilizers at the base
seal: a distinct head with a flat profile
lack of external ears (in true seals)
shark: gill slits on the sides of the head (usually 5-7)
pectoral fins located on the sides
skunk: Typically seen with a prominent white stripe running from the head down to the tail
skyscraper: could have antennas or spires on top
snail: a distinctive foot, used for movement
snake: potentially, a coiled or slithering posture
spider: multiple eyes, often in a particular arrangement
squirrel: often seen in trees or on the ground
table: often rectangular, square, round, or oval shape
four or more legs (can also have a central pedestal)
tank: a large cannon or main gun
telephone: recognizable brands or logos (like Apple, Samsung, etc. for smartphones)
earpiece and mouthpiece if it's a traditional phone
television: Remote control often nearby or visible in the scene
tiger: Rounded ears with white spots on the back
trout: adipose fin (a small, fleshy fin found between the dorsal fin and tail)
distinctive spots or markings on the body
wardrobe: May have handles or knobs on the doors
Doors on the front (can be swinging, sliding, or mirrored)
whale: specific markings or patterns, such as white belly patches or speckling
wolf: canid features that resemble those of a large dog
sharp, keen eyes, usually yellow or amber
worm: absence of a distinct head or eyes
